Award.AwardTitle: The 2016 Gainesville International Number Theory Conference
Award.AbstractNarration:
A five-day international number theory conference is planned for March 17-21, 2016, at the University of Florida, Gainesville. Research in number theory has a long history going back to the ancient Greeks. Recently research in number theory has made significant advances and has made important applications to other areas such as physics, computing, and data security. One such advance has been on gaps between prime numbers. The conference will feature three lectures by James Maynard on this topic. The conference continues a 15-year tradition at the University of Florida of conferences in number theory. There will be over thirty 40-minute and several 20-minute research presentations. Special effort will be given to support undergraduates, graduate students, post-doctoral scholars, women and minority participants, and those who have no other support.

The conference will cover the following topics: q-Series, partitions and modular forms, analytic number theory, and algebraic number theory. Historically the synergy between analytic number theory and the combinatorial/algebraic world of partitions and q-series has been extremely fruitful, starting with the collaboration of Hardy and Ramanujan. Throughout the twentieth century and into the twenty-first, we have seen each area enrich the other. For example, mid-twentieth century workers like Dyson and Atkin found fruitful interactions between these two areas, and the potential for further interactions along these lines by the participants in this conference is significant and tantalizing. The talks and papers of the conference will be widely disseminated by making presentations and abstracts available on the conference web page and by publishing a refereed conference proceedings. More information can be found at qseries.org/fgarvan/alladi60.html.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT  The main activity of the project was a five day Number Theory Conference in honor of Krishna Alladi's 60th Birthday. Number Theory is a branch of mathematics devoted to study of integers and their properties such the  distribution of prime numbers and integer solutions of equations. Modern Number Theory has important application to cryptography and secure data transmission. The topics of the conference included Analytic Number Theory, Algebraic Number Theory and the Theory of Partitions, q-Series and Modular Forms. Analytic Number Theory uses the methods of mathematical analysis to solve problems about integers such as the asymptotic distribution of prime numbers. Algebraic Number Theory uses the methods of abstract algebra to solve problems about integers. Partitions involve the additive problem of counting the ways of writing a number as a sum of other numbers and have important applications to statistical physics.  There were about 160 participants at the conference at all levels including 4 undergraduate students, 34 graduate students, 12 post-doctoral fellows, and 13 junior and 74 senior faculty. There were about 90 different talks with some in parallel sessions. There were special presentations by Hugh Montgomery (Michigan), James Maynard (Oxford) and Wadim Zudilin (Newcastle, Australia). In particular James Maynard presented his recent research on bounded gaps between prime numbers. Abstracts for all the conference talks are available on the conference website  http://www.qseries.org/alladi60/  as well as links to videos of many of the lectures. The conference provided a unique opportunity to bring together researchers and students in diverse yet overlapping fields of study. The proceedings of the conference consisting of over 30 research and expository papers on number theory and related subjects will be published by Springer.
